question: Question_08
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 4â12, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated,
simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions}.

A tank contains 1000 L (litres) of pure water. A solution that contains
0.01 kg/L of sugar is poured into the tank at a rate of 20 L/min. The
tank's contents are throughly mixed and drain out of the tank at the
same rate. How much sugar is in the tank after one hour?
sols:
Let $\displaystyle y(t)$ be the mass of sugar in the tank at time
$\displaystyle t$ (in minutes), with units of kg. The rate of change of
$\displaystyle y(t)$ is the difference between the incoming rate of salt
and the outgoing rate of salt. The rate is simply the concentration
multiplied by the flow rate; for incoming, we know the concentration is
0.01 kg/L and the flow rate is 20 L/min; for the outgoing, the
concentration is $\displaystyle y/1000$ and the flow rate is still 20
L/min.

\begin{align*}
\frac{dy}{dt} & = (\text{rate in}) - (\text{rate out}) \\
& = 0.01 \cdot 20 - \frac{y}{1000} \cdot 20 \\
& = \frac{10-y}{50}.
\end{align*}

If $\displaystyle y \neq 10$, then

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{10-y} \frac{dy}{dt} & = \frac{1}{50} \\
\int \frac{1}{10-y} \frac{dy}{dt} \ dt & = \int \frac{1}{50} \ dt \\
-\ln|10-y| & = \frac{1}{50}t + C
\end{align*}

We have an initial condition of $y(0) = 0$, so

\[\displaystyle 
-\ln 10 = C.\]

(Incidentally, this initial condition implies that
$\displaystyle y \neq 10$, since $\displaystyle y = 10$ is a
steady-state solution, where the mass never changes from 10.)

Now we solve

\begin{align*}
-\ln|10-y| & = \frac{1}{50}t - \ln 10 \\
|10-y| & = 10e^{-t/50}
\end{align*}

Since $\displaystyle y(t)$ is continuous, $\displaystyle 10-y(0) > 0$,
and the right-hand side of the equation above is always positive, we
conclude $\displaystyle 10-y(t) > 0$ for all $\displaystyle t$. Then

\begin{align*}
10-y & = 10e^{-t/50} \\
y & = 10-10e^{-t/50}
\end{align*}

The amount of sugar in the tank after 1 hour, or 60 minutes, is

\[\displaystyle 
y(60) = 10-10e^{-6/5}\]

relevant equation which relates the variables and quantities?

Don't forget the absolute value in $\ln |x|$. How does this affect
isolating for your desired variable?
What are the initial conditions, and how does that affect your solution?
